some work I'm doing in

So in this work, Zoe and I
are very interested in when

women are more
likely to speak out

against the imbalance and
the bias they see around them

and to stand up for themselves
and for other women.

And there are many
reasons for why

women may be more

motivated to speak out
and support driving

And in this work, we're
really interested in the role

that stereotype
threat has to play.

And by stereotype
threat, I'm referring

to the distracting
and often cognitive

resource-depleting
fear of confirming
negative stereotypes.

And here you see with
women in leadership.

And the reason we're
interested in this

is because, at first blush,
stereotype threat is typically

associated with very
deleterious outcomes in terms

of undermining performance
and reducing engagements,

motivation, and interest in the
negatively stereotyped domain.

However, we find
across three studies

that stereotype
threat can also be
fundamental to driving change.

So here's an overview
of the three studies.

The first two studies are
correlational studies.

In study one, we administer
a survey to MBA students

with global representation at a
unknown international graduate

business school with campuses
in Europe, Asia, and the Middle
East.

And in study two, we administer
a survey to all living alumni

from the same
business school, again

with global representation and
with significant leadership
experience.

So in both of these studies,
studies one and two,

we asked these global
business leaders and leaders

to be to report on
their experiences

with stereotype threat,
their school or work

engagements, and their change
motivations, both attitudinal

and behavioral support
for gender balance.

And then in study three,
this was an experiment that
was meant to assess causality.

And in the study, we
randomly assigned a sample

of working adult women
located at the United States

to either one of two
conditions, a control

condition or a stereotype
threat condition.

And then we measured
change motivations.

detail on a couple of slides.

So focusing first on
the first two studies,

the correlational
studies, we found

significant
correlational evidence

supporting that experiencing
stereotype threat

was linked with these
negative outcomes in terms

school or at work.

decades of past work

looking at negative
outcomes associated

However, importantly,

contribution, we find
